<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_init:
```c
int metal_init(const struct metal_init_params *params)
{
	int error = 0;

	if (_metal.common.ref_count++ != 0)
		return 0;

	memset(&_metal, 0, sizeof(_metal));

	_metal.common.log_handler   = params->log_handler;
	_metal.common.log_level     = params->log_level;

	metal_list_init(&_metal.common.bus_list);
	metal_list_init(&_metal.common.generic_shmem_list);
	metal_list_init(&_metal.common.generic_device_list);

	error = metal_sys_init(params);
	if (error)
		return error;

	++_metal.common.ref_count;
	return error;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragment in metal_init modifies the parameter 'params' itself. Specifically:
- if (_metal.common.ref_count++ != 0) and ++_metal.common.ref_count modify the global _metal object, not the parameter.
- memset(&_metal, 0, sizeof(_metal)) clears _metal, not params.
- _metal.common.log_handler = params->log_handler; and _metal.common.log_level = params->log_level; only read fields from params (allowed) and assign into _metal; they do not modify the pointer parameter or the object pointed to by params here.
- metal_list_init(...) calls do not touch params.
- error = metal_sys_init(params); only passes the pointer to another function. Even if that callee modifies the object pointed to by params, MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 permits modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter; the pointer variable itself is not being reassigned here.
Therefore there are no fragments in this function that violate Rule 17.8 and nothing to report for investigation.
